instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V43_G3H: What is PP3V43_G3H? This is a typo of PP3V42_G3H When you see PP3V43_G3H, assume they meant to type PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Hey, buddy, I got this mac had oxidation in component <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, replaces it. Probably the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> oxidized, too.
It doesn't spin the cooler, it's only safe green/orange.

Voltage: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.59V; <SIGNAL>PP3V43_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42V; <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5.14V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

Be aware, if <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> was bad, CPU could be affected too.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
If yes, then chek for pulse at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals.

Also try to start in SMC bypass mode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> was 3.41V when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> dropped to 0.35V.
replaces <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>  3.36V;


<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> 3.34V dropped to 0.14V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> 3.33V no change when triggering
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> 3.36V has dropped to 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL> 3.36V has dropped to 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 3.36 dropped to 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> 3.36V dropped to 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> there was no change when triggering .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
If you have steady <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals, no need for trigger test.
The problem is that you didn't mention that.
PLEASE, POST ACCURATE and USEFULL information from beggining...

Do you get voltage on all big coils, including VCORE?
What about <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
L7130 8.60/8.82V
L7520 0V
L7560 3.36V
L7430 0v
L7630 0v
L7310 0v
L7320 0v.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0v.
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 0v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 3.36 dropped to 0V"
When high, S3 voltages must appear.

"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> 3.36V dropped to 0v"
When high, S0 voltages must appear.

Now check again coils voltages, AT THE SAME TIME when you get high pulse on mentioned <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I don't know what happened, but the <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals
are all low, no need to trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I don't know how to interpret that.
How do you want to test, without triggering the power button???
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals must go high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: my friend, I don't have a high pulse on any of the <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX</SIGNAL> signals, even triggering the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>. I don't understand.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
You said <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>4_L</SIGNAL> drop from 3V to 0V.
In fact should go from 0V to 3V when you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

What is the actual state of your board?
Do you have mentioned signals high?
Drop to 0V when you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, or what?
Is very dificil to understand you, if do not post accurate information...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> high, I triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> was low. I tested the coils, Voltage:
L7130 1-8.59V/2- 8.85V
L7520 0v
L7560 3.36V
L7430 0v
L7630 0v
L7310 0v
L7320 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Specify which <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> goes high.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> controls L7430 voltage.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> controls L7630...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 3.36V/ <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> 3.36V, previously did not have these voltages, and when I activate <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> the voltage drops to 0v in <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL>.

All <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals drop from 3.36v to 0V when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered.



Note: I used another io/power in this test, it was not lack of accuracy in the test.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Why do you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, if the board is already turned on???
This test is supposed to be used when the board is off.
Please, make use of logic.

All this happens because you do not explain correctly the symptoms.

When all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals are high, check which voltages appear on the big coils (secondary supplies).
Also check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 62119, member: 682"]
When all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals are high, check which voltages appear on the big coils (secondary supplies).
[/QUOTE]
Right.

Coils:
L7130 8.60/8.65V
L7520 5.14V
L7560 3.34V
L7430 1.2VV
L7630 0V
L7310 0V
L7320 0V

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0.72V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
"L7630 0V"
It must go high, at same time with <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>.
In fact is controlled by <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL>, which comes from <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>; check if pulses at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Do you mean steady 3V at <SIGNAL>PM_SP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL>?
Then you should have 3V at pin 16/<CHIP>U7600</CHIP> too; unless <RESISTOR>R8185</RESISTOR> is open.

Post some voltages for <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>; pins 12, 16, 17, 6, 5, 9.
Check R/<CAPACITOR>C7630</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 62334, member: 682"]
Você quer dizer 3V constante em <SIGNAL>PM_SP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL>?
[/QUOTE] 3.34V  steady.
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 62334, member: 682"]
Verifique R / <CAPACITOR>C7630</CAPACITOR>.
[/QUOTE] are fine.


<CHIP>U7600</CHIP>
12 - 5.15V
16- 3.34V
17- 0.05V
6- 0V
5- 0.14V
9- 0.18V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Post diode mode to ground at L7630.
If good, change <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>.

comparing another board I present 0.201V diod scale.
